In botany, a drupe (or stone fruit) is an indehiscent fruit in which an outer fleshy part (exocarp, or skin; and mesocarp, or flesh) surrounds a single shell (the pit, stone, or pyrene) of hardened endocarp with a seed (kernel) inside. Familiar examples include the stonefruits of the genus "Prunus" (peaches, plums and cherries), olives, coconut, bayberry and "Persea" species. The term "drupaceous" is used of fruits that have the general structure and texture of a drupe, without necessarily meeting the full definition.
